messages: 7e7225a5c539a1a7a64ab01d929e1c2f (05:53): when i do -p ! icmp it complains it dosn't know what -dport is... yet it says i can do this in the man pages i'm using iptables 1.3.5
de76c8e6cbbc3c1c44788a340cac141e (05:55): you're reading the manpage wrong then
de76c8e6cbbc3c1c44788a340cac141e (05:55): where does it say that?
de76c8e6cbbc3c1c44788a340cac141e (05:55): you need to use -p tcp (or -p udp) to use --dport
7e7225a5c539a1a7a64ab01d929e1c2f (05:56): -p, --protocol [!] protocol
7e7225a5c539a1a7a64ab01d929e1c2f (05:57): ! icmp, should mean to use tcp and udp but not icmp
de76c8e6cbbc3c1c44788a340cac141e (05:57): um, no
de76c8e6cbbc3c1c44788a340cac141e (05:57): there's more than 3 choices
7e7225a5c539a1a7a64ab01d929e1c2f (05:57): instead of speficying 2 rules 1 for udp 1 for tcp
7e7225a5c539a1a7a64ab01d929e1c2f (05:57): udp, tcp, icmp, all
de76c8e6cbbc3c1c44788a340cac141e (05:57): " or it can be a numeric value, representing one of these protocols or a different one."
7e7225a5c539a1a7a64ab01d929e1c2f (05:57): well not icmp should mean only udp and tcp in my books
de76c8e6cbbc3c1c44788a340cac141e (05:58): nope
de76c8e6cbbc3c1c44788a340cac141e (05:58): not icmp means not icmp
7e7225a5c539a1a7a64ab01d929e1c2f (05:58): as all wouldn't be valid if not icmp
7e7225a5c539a1a7a64ab01d929e1c2f (05:58): i can't do -p tcp,udp can i?
de76c8e6cbbc3c1c44788a340cac141e (05:58): all != tcp,udp,icmp
de76c8e6cbbc3c1c44788a340cac141e (05:58): no you can't
7e7225a5c539a1a7a64ab01d929e1c2f (05:59): so i'm stuck with making 2 rules todo udp and tcp...
de76c8e6cbbc3c1c44788a340cac141e (05:59): yes
de76c8e6cbbc3c1c44788a340cac141e (05:59): you can use multiport to group the TCP ports together
7e7225a5c539a1a7a64ab01d929e1c2f (05:59): be nice if ya could do -s tcp,udp
7e7225a5c539a1a7a64ab01d929e1c2f (05:59): how do i go aobut that?
de76c8e6cbbc3c1c44788a340cac141e (06:00): -A INPUT -p tcp -m multiport --dports 80,443 -j ACCEPT
7e7225a5c539a1a7a64ab01d929e1c2f (06:00): ah i see it in the man page
de76c8e6cbbc3c1c44788a340cac141e (06:00): up to 15 ports in the list, you can use ranges
7e7225a5c539a1a7a64ab01d929e1c2f (06:01): ah that answeres another thing i wasn't too sure on but there isn't such a thing for the port type
de76c8e6cbbc3c1c44788a340cac141e (06:02): port type?
7e7225a5c539a1a7a64ab01d929e1c2f (06:02): oh i ment to type protocol type sorry
7e7225a5c539a1a7a64ab01d929e1c2f (06:02): i'm still half asleep here
de76c8e6cbbc3c1c44788a340cac141e (06:02): you could make one, but then --dport wouldn't work
de76c8e6cbbc3c1c44788a340cac141e (06:03): the --dport for UDP is a different function than the --dport for TCP
7e7225a5c539a1a7a64ab01d929e1c2f (06:03): ah then i'm back to doing it the old way then.
7e7225a5c539a1a7a64ab01d929e1c2f (06:03): jsut thought there be a less lines method but oviously not
7e7225a5c539a1a7a64ab01d929e1c2f (06:04): thanks for that.
